unnormalised: Someone asked me if investing in penny stocks is like betting on the IPL. Well, kinda, but with slightly better odds... maybe. Look, both involve risk, excitement, and the potential to lose your chai-paani money. Seriously though, I wouldn't recommend putting your life savings into either. Think of it this way: a good stock, like a well-made dosa, takes time and the right ingredients. A penny stock is more like that vada you bought from the roadside stall - cheap, potentially delicious, but also could give you a stomach ache.

unnormalised: Now, I'm no investment guru; I once bought a stock based on a dream (don't ask!), and let's just say my portfolio looked like the score after a India vs Pakistan cricket match – mostly zeroes. But seriously folks, do your research! Don't just listen to your chacha's friend who "knows a guy" who's "guaranteed" to make you a millionaire. Read articles, understand the market, and maybe consult a proper financial advisor (unless they also got their advice from a dream).

unnormalised: At the end of the day, investing is a bit like ordering food online. You see that juicy-looking biryani (high-potential stock) but there's a chance it'll arrive cold (market crash). So, start small, diversify your portfolio (like ordering a thali instead of just one dish), and don't invest more than you can afford to lose. And for heaven's sake, don't take investment advice from a guy on Quora... even if he is kinda funny. Especially if it's about DogeCoin or other Meme stocks! (Rs. 100 invested can become Rs. 1, only joking, maybe.)
